Author: Young, Jeffrey R.
Title: Why Students Should Own Their Educational Data, Why Students Should Own Their Educational Data
Publication Title: The Chronicle of Higher Education Blogs: Wired Campus
Notes:
Young, 2014 Notes.

  • Prof. Rose (HGSE) argues because learners have more of a "jagged profile" in their learning, the traditional assumption of teaching to the middle does not work- this idea of "the average learner".
    • NB: "jagged profile" means grasping key concepts/ skills/ knowledge in some areas more quickly and easily than others.
  • Technology can be harnessed to personalize teaching resources in line with students' strengths, weaknesses, interests etc.
  • Part of the issue is that dominant pedagogy is based on findings from statistical analysis which focus on understanding the population rather than the individual.
    •  We need to bring the level of analysis down a few levels, to be of any good:
    • Claims "learning styles falls apart [it} comes from analyzing a population...But when you apply it to one individual it doesn't hold"
    • Now "we're looking for personal patterns across what we call dimensions"
  • We can now do this individual analysis because there is more data available.
  • But, this is complicated by an individuals' learning components (flbt) moving and shifting- e.g. personality, which changes according to each context and the various factors making up that context.
  • When talking about MOOCs, Prof. Rose thinks the real break-through is that it has brought to the fore discussions around the "value proposition" of face to face learning over online learning.
    •  Linked to this, believes students should have ownership over MOOC data- "right now...everybody but the user owns their data".
    • This feeds into the push for learning data being collected and analyzed (used) at that individual level. Without more transparency, this "new science of the individual" will be hindered.

Author: Clow, Doug
Title: Data wranglers: human interpreters to help close the feedback loop
Notes:
Doug Clow, 2014, Notes

  • Article outlines benefits of LA cycle and use of Data Wranglers as "human sense-makers" p.3. Describes and analyzes pilot to embed DW in a HE institution.
  • LA cycle: data analysis and feedback loops which produce "actionable intelligence" ultimately to improve learning.
    • Clow notes actionable doesn't mean it always is implemented smartly-namely institutionalizing the LA approach, engaging staff at all stages, building community of practice around the data, and working towards double-loop learning.
    • Central to the LA cycle is the role of human in "interpreting the data, engaging in sense-making activities to mediate the information" that then leads to action. Humans are needed because this information is complex, multi-faceted, reflective of the learning process itself.
  • Single-loop learning: working towards a LA goal.
  • Double-loop learning: questioning the goals, refining them, and working towards them while trying to improve the data too (more cyclical).
  • This paper describes a pilot where a team of Data Wranglers worked to embed this LA cycle in each Faculty of the Open University.
    •  They had regular communication with staff, sat in on discussions, built staff data literacy capacity, undertook further research & analysis as needed, and fed into learning design.
  • Found the DW "activity is one component of a large, common system of quality assurance and quality enhancement" p.4
  • DW reports provided evidence to theories of course design and assessment and also about online instructional design- not revealing anything new, just showing these were highly applicable to the OU context. p.4
  • Evaluation of the pilot yielded mixed results: student retention, completion, feedback etc (all to improve the learning experience) declined, though changes in the context within which OU operates are likely to have influenced this.
    •  Also, the timescale for implementing suggested changes to course design have a time lag- since courses take 1-3 years to develop. p.5
    • Stakeholder feedback was positive and anecdotal evidence demonstrated increased use of data, or use of data to inspire useful discussions.
    • DW outputs and reactions to these differed across faculties.
    • Data quality varied also across faculties- and were only recognized through attempts to analyze that data.
  • Conclusion was that the real success of DW was their ability to present data strategically to trigger discussions and planning around learning at an organizational level.
